revision.text:
{{Infobox medical condition | name = Exercise intolerance | image = File:E312 (CardioNetworks ECGpedia).jpg | alt = | caption = EKG of a 70-year-old man with exercise intolerance | pronounce = | field = | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|R68.89}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|V47.2}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | MeSH = | GeneReviewsNBK = | GeneReviewsName = }}
'''Exercise intolerance''' is a condition of inability or decreased ability to perform [[physical exercise]] at what would be considered to be the normally expected level or duration. It also includes experiences of unusually severe post-exercise [[pain]], [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]], [[nausea]], [[vomiting]] or other negative effects. Exercise intolerance is not a [[disease]] or [[syndrome]] in and of itself, but can result from various disorders.
In most cases, the specific reason that exercise is not tolerated is of considerable significance when trying to isolate the cause down to a specific disease. Dysfunctions involving the pulmonary, cardiovascular or neuromuscular systems have been frequently found to be associated with exercise intolerance, with behavioural causes also playing a part.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://pedsinreview.aappublications.org/content/21/1/6.extract|title = Exercise Intolerance|date = 2000|accessdate = 2015-04-17|journal = Pediatrics in Review|volume = 21|issue = 1|pages = 6–9|last = Scott Owens|first = Bernard Gutin|doi = 10.1542/pir.21-1-6|pmid = 10617757}}</ref>
==Causes==
===Respiratory disorders=== *[[Cystic fibrosis]]: CF can cause skeletal muscle atrophy, however more commonly it can cause exercise intolerance. The exercise intolerance is associated with reduced pulmonary function that is the origin of CF.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Infection, inflammation and exercise in cystic fibrosis|last = Van de Weert-van Leeuwen|first = Pauline|date = 2013|journal =Respiratory Research|doi = 10.1186/1465-9921-14-32|pmid = 23497303|pmc=3599254|volume=14|pages=32}}</ref> *[[Bronchiectasis]]
===Chronic fatigue syndrome=== * [[Orthostatic intolerance]] (OI) occurs in CFS. OI includes exercise intolerance as one of the main symptoms. It also includes fatigue, nausea, headaches, cognitive problems and visual disturbances as other less major symptoms.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Predictors of post-infectious chronic fatigue syndrome in adolescents|last = Leonard|first = Jason|date = 2014-01-01|journal = Health Psychology and Behavioural Medicine|doi = 10.1080/21642850.2013.869176|pmid = 24660116|pmc=3956649|volume=2|issue = 1|pages=41–51}}</ref>
===Post-concussion syndrome=== * Exercise intolerance is present in those with PCS however their intolerance to exercise may reduce over time.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Exercise Intolerance in Individuals With Postconcussion Syndrome|last = Kozlowski|first = Karl F.|date = 2013|journal = Journal of Athletic Training|doi = 10.4085/1062-6050-48.5.02|pmid = 23952041|pmc=3784364|volume=48|issue = 5|pages=627–35}}</ref> * Individuals with [[postconcussion syndrome]] may also experience a level of exercise intolerance, however there is little known comparatively about exercise intolerance in PCS patients.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Exercise Intolerance in Individuals With Postconcussion Syndrome|last = Kozlowski|first = Karl F|date = 2013|journal = Journal of Athletic Training|doi = 10.4085/1062-6050-48.5.02|pmid = 23952041|first2 = James|last2 = Graham|issue = 5|volume = 48|pages = 627–635|pmc=3784364}}</ref>
===Heart conditions=== *[[Heart failure]]: Exercise intolerance is a primary symptom of chronic [[diastolic]] heart failure.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Exercise Intolerance|date = 2011|journal = Cardiology Clinics|last = Dalane W. Kitzman|first = Leanne Groban|pmc=3694583|pmid=21803233|doi=10.1016/j.ccl.2011.06.002|volume=29|issue = 3|pages=461–77}}</ref> *[[Cardiac arrhythmia]] *[[Aortic valve insufficiency]] *[[Pulmonary artery hypertension]]: PAH has the following symptoms; dyspnea and fatigue, these systems consequently contribute to exercise intolerance.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Exercise Intolerance in Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension|last = Fowler|first = Robin|date = 2012|journal = Pulmonary Medicine|doi = 10.1155/2012/359204|pmid = 22737582|pmc=3377355|volume=June|pages=1–10}}</ref> *Asymptomatic [[atrial septal defect]]s; In the heart the right ventricular (RV) can have a volume overload which ultimately produces a pressure overload in the RV resulting in exercise intolerance as the RV is no longer able to control high pressure associated with exercise.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Atrial septal defects|last = Geva|first = Professor Tal|date = 2014|journal = The Lancet|doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(13)62145-5|pmid = 24725467|volume=383|issue = 9932|pages=1921–1932}}</ref> *[[Chronic heart failure]]
===Musculoskeletal disorders=== *[[Spinal muscular atrophy]]: symptoms include exercise intolerance, cognitive impairment and fatigue.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Motor Neuron Syndrome as a New Phenotypic Manifestation of Mutation 9185T>C in Gene MTATP6|last = Brum|first = Marisa|date = 2014|journal = Case Rep Neurol Med|doi = 10.1155/2014/701761|pmid = 25548692|pmc = 4274829|volume=2014|pages=1–4}}</ref> *[[Rhabdomyolysis]]: a condition in which muscle degrades, releasing intracellular muscle content into the blood as reflected by elevated blood levels of [[creatine kinase]].<ref>{{cite journal|pmc=4908773|year=2016|author1=Chavez|first1=L. O.|title=Beyond muscle destruction: A systematic review of rhabdomyolysis for clinical practice|journal=Critical Care|volume=20|issue=1|pages=135|last2=Leon|first2=M|last3=Einav|first3=S|last4=Varon|first4=J|doi=10.1186/s13054-016-1314-5|pmid=27301374}}</ref> Exercise tolerance is significantly compromised.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=22616958|year=2012|author1=Quinlivan|first1=R|title=Myopathic causes of exercise intolerance with rhabdomyolysis|journal=Developmental Medicine and Child Neurology|volume=54|issue=10|pages=886–91|last2=Jungbluth|first2=H|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8749.2012.04320.x}}</ref>
===Mutations=== *[[Mitochondrial complex 111]]: Currently it is suggested that there are 27 different mutations identified in cytochrome ''b ''(mitochondrial complex III is one of those mutations). This mutation can often lead to skeletal muscle weakness and as a result exercise intolerance.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Mitochondrial Complex III Deficiency Associated with a Homozygous Mutation in UQCRQ|last = Barel|first = Ortal|date = 2008|journal = The American Journal of Human Genetics|doi = 10.1016/j.ajhg.2008.03.020|pmid = 18439546|pmc=2427202|volume=82|issue = 5|pages=1211–6}}</ref> *[[a complex of Coenzyme Q10]]: *[[Skeletal muscle respiratory chain defect]]: This can result in severe exercise intolerance which is manifested by the following symptoms of Skeletal muscle respiratory chain defect; muscle fatigue and lactic acidosis.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Exercise intolerance, lactic acidosis, and abnormal cardiopulmonary regulation in exercise associated with adult skeletal muscle cytochrome c oxidase deficiency|last = Haller|first = R.G|date = 1989|journal = The Journal of Clinical Investigation|doi = 10.1172/JCI114135|pmid = 2544623|pmc=303965|volume=84|issue = 1|pages=155–61}}</ref> * Exercise tolerance reflects the combined capacity of components in the oxygen cascade to supply adequate oxygen for ATP resynthesis. In individuals with diseases such as cancer, certain therapies can affect one or more components of this cascade and therefore reduce the body's ability to utilise or deliver oxygen, leading to exercise intolerance.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1016/S1470-2045(09)70031-2|pmid=19482248|title=Exercise intolerance in cancer and the role of exercise therapy to reverse dysfunction|journal=The Lancet Oncology|volume=10|issue=6|pages=598–605|year=2009|last1=Jones|first1=Lee W.|last2=Eves|first2=Neil D.|last3=Haykowsky|first3=Mark|last4=Freedland|first4=Stephen J.|last5=MacKey|first5=John R.}}</ref>
=== Cytochrome b mutations === [[Cytochrome b]] mutations can frequently cause isolated exercise intolerance and myopathy and in some cases multisystem disorders. The mitochondrial respiratory chain complex III catalyses electron transfer to cytochrome c. Complex III is embedded in the inner membrane of the mitochondria and consists of 11 subunits. Cytochrome b is encoded by the mitochondrial DNA which differs from all other subunits which are encoded in the nucleus. Cytochrome b plays a major part in the correct fabricating and function of complex III.
This mutation occurred in an 18-year-old man who had experienced exercise intolerance for most of his adolescence. Symptoms included extreme fatigue, nausea, a decline in physical activity ability and myalgia.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
===Intracranial hypertension=== Individuals with elevated levels of cerebrospinal fluid can experience increased head pain, throbbing, pulsatile tinnitus, nausea and vomiting, faintness and weakness and even loss of consciousness after exercise or exertion.
== Treatment == Exercise is key for many heart and back patients, and a variety of specific exercise techniques are available for both groups. Some exercise specialists are trained in modifications specific to these patients{{Who|date=August 2009}}.
In individuals with [[heart failure]] and normal [[Ejection fraction|EF (ejection fraction)]], including aortic distensibility, blood pressure, LV diastolic compliance and skeletal muscle function, aerobic exercise has the potential to improve exercise tolerance. A variety of pharmacological interventions such as [[verapamil]], [[enalapril]], angiotensin receptor antagonism, and aldosterone antagonism could potentially improve exercise tolerance in these individuals as well.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Exercise Intolerance|last = Kitzman|first = Delane W|date = 2005|journal = Progress in Cardiovascular Diseases|doi = 10.1016/j.pcad.2005.02.002|pmid = 16115516|issue = 6|volume = 47|pages = 367–379}}</ref>
Research on individuals suffering from [[Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease|Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)]], has found a number of effective therapies in relation to exercise intolerance. These include: # [[Oxygen supplementation|Oxygen Supplementation]] #* Reduces carotid body drive and slows respiration at a given level of exercise. # Treatment with [[bronchodilators]] #* Clinically useful improvements in expiratory airflow, allows fuller exhalation in a given period of time, reduces dynamic hyperinflation, and prolongs exercise tolerance. # [[Heliox]] (79% Helium, 21% oxygen) #* Heliox has a lower density than air. #* Breathing heliox lowers expiratory airflow resistance, decreases dynamic hyperinflation, and prolongs exercise tolerance. # High intensity rehabilitative exercise training #* Increasing the fitness of muscles decreases the amount of lactic acid released at any given level of exercise. #* Since lactic acid stimulates respiration, after rehabilitative training exercising, ventilation is lower, respiration is slowed, and dynamic hyperinflation is reduced. A combination of these therapies (Combined therapies), have shown the potential to improve exercise tolerance as well.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Combination therapy for exercise intolerance in COPD|last = Casaburi|first = R|date = 2006|journal = Thorax|doi = 10.1136/thx.2006.058511|pmid = 16807386|issue = 7|volume = 61|pages = 551–552|pmc = 2104677}}</ref>
===Hazards=== Certain conditions exist where exercise may be [[contraindicated]] or should be performed under the direction of an experienced and licensed medical professional acting within his or her scope of practice. These conditions include:
*Decompensated [[heart failure]] *Recent [[myocardial infarction]] *[[Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy]] or [[cardiomyopathy]] from recent [[myocarditis]] *Active or suspected myocarditis or [[pericarditis]] *Low left ventricular [[ejection fraction]] *Severe [[aortic stenosis]] *Unstable [[ischemia]] *Unstable [[arrythmia]] *Irregular or [[resting pulse]] greater than 100 bpm *Resting [[systolic blood pressure]] >200 mm Hg or resting [[diastolic blood pressure]] >110 mm Hg *Severe [[pulmonary hypertension]] *Severe [[chronic fatigue syndrome]] *Suspected or known [[dissecting aortic aneurysm]] *Recent systemic or [[pulmonary embolus]] *[[Pneumothorax]] and [[haemoptysis]] *[[thrombophlebitis]]
The above list does not include all potential contraindications or precautions to exercise. Although it has not been shown to promote improved muscle strength, passive range-of-motion exercise is sometimes used to prevent skin breakdown and prevent contractures in patients unable to safely self-power.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Exercise Intolerance}} [[Category:Symptoms]] [[Category:Physical exercise]] [[Category:Exercise physiology]]

revision.text:
[[File:The genetic and molecular basis of idiopathic hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.jpg|thumb|upright=1.6|The genetic and molecular basis of idiopathic hypogonadotropic hypogonadism]]
To date at least twenty five different genes have been implicated in causing [[GnRH]] deficiency conditions such [[Kallmann syndrome]] (KS) or other forms of [[hypogonadotropic hypogonadism]] through a disruption in the production or activity of GnRH. These genes involved cover all forms of [[inheritance]] and no one gene defect has been shown to be common to all cases which makes genetic testing and inheritance prediction difficult.<ref name="pmid:23650337">{{cite journal |author=Layman L. |title=Clinical Testing for Kallmann Syndrome. |journal=J Clin Endocrinol Metab |volume=98 |issue=5 |pages=1860–1862 |year=2013 |pmid=23650337 |doi=10.1210/jc.2013-1624 |pmc=3644595}}</ref><ref name="pmid:25071724">{{cite journal |author=Valdes-Socin H, Rubio Almanza M, Tomé Fernández-Ladreda M, Debray FG, Bours V, Beckers A |title=Reproduction, smell, and neurodevelopmental disorders: genetic defects in different hypogonadotropic hypogonadal syndromes. |journal=Front Endocrinol (Lausanne) |volume=5 |issue=109 |pages= 109|year=2014 |pmc=4088923 |doi=10.3389/fendo.2014.00109 |pmid=25071724}}</ref>
The number of genes known to cause cases of KS / CHH is still increasing.<ref name="pmid21511493">{{cite journal |author=Mitchell AL, Dwyer A, Pitteloud N, Quinton R |title=Genetic basis and variable phenotypic expression of Kallmann syndrome: towards a unifying theory. |journal=Trends Endocrinol. Metab. |volume=22 |issue=7 |pages=249–58 |year=2011 |pmid=21511493 |doi=10.1016/j.tem.2011.03.002}}</ref> In addition it is thought that some cases of KS / CHH are caused by two separate gene defects occurring at the same time.<ref name="pmid:28476224">{{cite journal |author=Lima Amato LG, Latronico AC, Gontijo Silveira LF |title=Molecular and Genetic Aspects of Congenital Isolated Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism |journal=Endocrinol Metab Clin North Am |volume=46 |issue=2 |pages=283–303 |year=2017 |pmid=28476224 |doi=10.1016/j.ecl.2017.01.010}}</ref>
==Genes== A table of known genes responsible for cases of GnRH deficiency conditions is shown below. Listed are the estimated prevalence of cases caused by the specific gene, additional associated symptoms and the form of inheritance.<ref name="pmid:28476224"/><ref name="pmid:26194704">{{cite journal |vauthors=Boehm U, Bouloux PM, Dattani MT, etal |title=Expert consensus document: European Consensus Statement on congenital hypogonadotropic hypogonadism-pathogenesis, diagnosis and treatment. |journal=Nat Rev Endocrinol |volume= 11|issue=Jul 21 |pages= 547–64|year=2015 |pmid=26194704 |doi=10.1038/nrendo.2015.112}}</ref> Between 35-45% of cases of KS / CHH have an unknown genetic cause.<ref name="pmid:26934720">{{cite journal |author=Vezzoli V, Duminuco P, Bassi I, Guizzardi F, Persani L, Bonomi M |title=The complex genetic basis of congenital hypogonadotropic hypogonadism |journal=Minerva Endocrinol |volume=41 |issue=2 |pages=223–39 |year=2016 |pmid=26934720 |doi=}}</ref>

{{distinguish|text = the [[Holyoke Water Power Company]], a defunct energy utility}} {{Infobox government agency | agency_name = Holyoke Water Works | type = | nativename_a = | nativename_r = | logo = HolyokeWaterWorks.svg | logo_width = 200px | logo_caption = Official wordmark of the HWW | seal = | seal_width = | seal_caption = | picture = | picture_width = | picture_caption = | formed = {{Start date and age|1872|03|07|df=yes|p=yes|br=yes}} | preceding1 = | preceding2 = | dissolved = | superseding = | jurisdiction = [[Holyoke]] & [[Southampton, Massachusetts|Southampton]] | headquarters = 20 Commercial Street
[[Holyoke]], [[Massachusetts|MA]] 01040 | coordinates = | motto = | employees = 25 (2016){{cite news|url=https://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2016/02/holyoke_water_rates_increased.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160224115846/https://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2016/02/holyoke_water_rates_increased.html|archive-date= February 24, 2016 |title= Holyoke water rates increased for 1st time since 2009 but next could come sooner |last= Plaisance |first=Mike |date= February 21, 2016 |quote= For example, Water Works had 48 employees in 2000 and today has 25}} | budget = $5,373,834 (FY 2017){{cite report |title= City of Holyoke, Massachusetts; Appropriations Budget for the Fiscal Year, July 1, 2016 – June 30, 2017 |year=2016 |page=4 |publisher= City of Holyoke}} | chief1_name = David M. Conti | chief1_position = General Manager | chief2_name = Butch D. Seidel | chief2_position = Supervisor, Source of Supply | agency_type = Municipal | parent_department = Holyoke Board of Water Commissioners | parent_agency = | child1_agency = | child2_agency = | keydocument1 = An Act to Supply the Town of Holyoke with Pure Water (1872, c. 62) | website = {{URL|https://www.holyoke.org/departments/water-works}} | footnotes = | map = | map_width = | map_caption = }} The '''Holyoke Water Works (HWW)''', sometimes referred to as the '''Holyoke Reservoir System''', is a public [[drinking water]] utility and [[municipal service]] agency of the City of {{w|Holyoke, Massachusetts}}, which provides clean drinking water to that city. Founded in 1872 by an act of {{w|Massachusetts General Court}}, the system was developed as a series of reservoirs to serve the growing city's residents and industry at the end of the 19th century. Today its primary drinking water source is the Tighe-Carmody Reservoir in [[Southampton, Massachusetts]], while it maintains reserve drinking water supplies at the [[Ashley Reservoir|Ashley]] and the [[Whiting Street Reservoir]]s.{{cite report|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180709175102/http://www.pvpc.org/sites/default/files/Holyoke_HMP_Update_2016.pdf|archive-date=2018-07-09|url=http://www.pvpc.org/sites/default/files/Holyoke_HMP_Update_2016.pdf|publisher=Pioneer Valley Planning Commission|author=The Holyoke Hazard Mitigation Planning Committee|title=City of Holyoke, Natural Hazards Mitigation Plan Update}} The Water Works is entirely responsible for drinking water supplies, infrastructure, and watershed land conservancy, however it does not maintain sewage or stormwater treatment infrastructure or services, which fall under the responsibilities [[Holyoke Department of Public Works|Department of Public Works]].{{cite web|url=https://www.holyoke.org/departments/public-works/|title=Public Works|website=City of Holyoke|access-date=July 10, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2018/01/warnings_and_water_shut_off_lo.html|title=Warnings and water shut off looming for Holyoke sewer bill delinquents|last=Plaisance|first=Mike|work=MassLive|location=Springfield, Mass.|date=January 11, 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.holyoke.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/2017-CCR.pdf 2017 Consumer Confidence Report], Holyoke Water Works {{Holyoke, Massachusetts}} {{Watersupply-stub}} [[Category:Government of Holyoke, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Southampton, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Water supply and sanitation in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Water management authorities in the United States]] [[Category:Water companies of the United States]] [[Category:1872 establishments in Massachusetts]]

revision.comment: I don't see this as an "unreliable medical source" as it is authored by an MD in a peer reviewed journal
revision.text:
{{medref|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}}
In medicine, the '''hygiene hypothesis''' states a lack of early childhood exposure to [[infectious agents]], [[symbiotic]] microorganisms (such as the [[gut flora]] or [[probiotic]]s), and [[parasite]]s increases susceptibility to [[allergy|allergic]] diseases by suppressing the natural development of the [[immune system]]. In particular, the lack of exposure is thought to lead to defects in the establishment of [[immune tolerance]].
The hygiene hypothesis has also been called the "[[biome]] depletion theory" and the "lost friends theory".<ref name=parker>{{cite web| url=http://evmedreview.com/?p=457/ |author=William Parker |title=Reconstituting the depleted biome to prevent immune disorders|publisher=The Evolution & Medicine Review |date=2010-10-13| accessdate=2014-03-31}}</ref>
== Overview ==
The original formulation of the hygiene hypothesis dates from 1989 when David Strachan proposed that lower incidence of [[infection]] in early childhood could be an explanation for the rapid 20th century rise in allergic diseases such as [[asthma]] and [[hay fever]].<ref name=strachan2000>{{Cite journal | last1 = Strachan | first1 = D. | title = Family size, infection and atopy: The first decade of the 'hygiene hypothesis' | doi = 10.1136/thorax.55.suppl_1.S2 | journal = Thorax | volume = 55 | issue = 90001 | pages = S2–S10 | year = 2000 | pmid = | pmc = 1765943}}</ref>
It is now also recognised that the "reduced microbial exposure" concept applies to a much broader range of [[chronic inflammatory disease]]s than asthma and hay fever, which includes diseases such as [[type 1 diabetes]]<ref name=stene2001>Stene LC, Nafstad P. Relation between occurrence of type 1 diabetes and asthma" ''Lancet'' 2001;357:607</ref> and multiple sclerosis,<ref name=raison2010>Raison CL, Lowry CA, Rook GAW. Inflammation, sanitation and consternation: loss of contact with co-evolved, tolerogenic micro-organisms and the pathophysiology and treatment of major depression" ''Arch Gen Psychiatry'' 2010;67(12) 1211-24</ref> and also some types of depression<ref name=raison2010 /><ref name=rook2013>{{Cite journal | last1 = Rook | first1 = G. A. W. | last2 = Lowry | first2 = C. A. | last3 = Raison | first3 = C. L. | title = Microbial 'Old Friends', immunoregulation and stress resilience | doi = 10.1093/emph/eot004 | journal = Evolution, Medicine, and Public Health | volume = 2013 | issue = 1 | pages = 46–64 | year = 2013 | pmid = | pmc = 3868387}}</ref> and cancer.<ref name=rook2011>{{cite journal |vauthors=Rook GA, Dalgleish A | year = 2011 | title = Infection, immunoregulation and cancer | url = | journal = Immunological Reviews | volume = 240 | issue = 1| pages = 141–59 | doi=10.1111/j.1600-065x.2010.00987.x| pmid = 21349092 }}</ref>{{specify|date=March 2015}}
In 2003 Graham Rook proposed the "old friends hypothesis" which some claim offers a more rational explanation for the link between microbial exposure and inflammatory disorders.<ref name=rook2003>Rook GA, Martinelli R, Brunet LR. Innate immune responses to mycobacteria and the downregulation of atopic responses" ''Curr Opin Allergy Clin Immunol'' 2003 Oct;3(5) 337-42.</ref> He argues that the vital microbial exposures are not colds, influenza, measles and other common childhood infections which have evolved relatively recently over the last 10,000 years, but rather the microbes already present during mammalian and human evolution, that could persist in small hunter gatherer groups as microbiota, tolerated latent infections or carrier states. He proposes that humans have become so dependent on these "old friends" that their immune systems neither develop properly nor function properly without them.
Strachan's original formulation of the hygiene hypothesis also centred around the idea that smaller families provided insufficient microbial exposure partly because of less person-to-person spread of infections, but also because of "improved household amenities and higher standards of personal cleanliness".<ref name=strachan2000 /> It seems likely that this was the reason he named it the "hygiene hypothesis". Although the "hygiene revolution" of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries may have been a major factor, it now seems more likely that, although public health measures such as [[sanitation]], [[potable water]] and [[garbage collection]] were instrumental in reducing our exposure to [[cholera]], [[typhoid]] and so on, they also deprived people of their exposure to the "old friends" that occupy the same environmental habitats.<ref name=stanwellsmith>{{cite web |authors=Stanwell-Smith R, Bloomfield SF, Rook GA. |title=The hygiene hypothesis and its implications for home hygiene, lifestyle and public health. |publisher=International Scientific Forum on Home Hygiene. |url=http://www.ifh-homehygiene.org/best-practice-review/hygiene-hypothesis-and-its-implications-home-hygiene-lifestyle-and-public-0 |year=2012}}</ref><ref name=Bloomfield >Bloomfield SF, Stanwell-Smith R, Rook GA. (2012) The hygiene hypothesis and its implications for home hygiene, lifestyle and public health: summary. International Scientific Forum on Home Hygiene. http://www.ifh-homehygiene.org/best-practice-review/hygiene-hypothesis-and-its-implications-home-hygiene-lifestyle-and-public</ref>
The rise of [[autoimmune disease]]s and [[acute lymphoblastic leukemia]] in young people in the developed world was linked to the hygiene hypothesis.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Smith | first1 = M. A. | last2 = Simon | first2 = R. | last3 = Strickler | first3 = H. D. | last4 = McQuillan | first4 = G. | last5 = Gloeckler Ries | first5 = L. A. | last6 = Linet | first6 = M. S. | journal = Cancer Causes & Control | volume = 9 | issue = 3 | pages = 285–298 |title=Evidence that Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia is Associated with an Infectious Agent Linked to Hygiene Conditions| year = 1998 | doi = 10.1023/A:1008873103921 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref><ref name=Okada2010>{{Cite journal | last1 = Okada | first1 = H. | last2 = Kuhn | first2 = C. | last3 = Feillet | first3 = H. | last4 = Bach | first4 = J. -F. | title = The 'hygiene hypothesis' for autoimmune and allergic diseases: An update | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2249.2010.04139.x | journal = Clinical & Experimental Immunology | volume = 160 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–9 | year = 2010 | pmid = | pmc = 2841828}}</ref>
Some evidence indicates that [[autism]] is correlated to factors (such as certain [[cytokines]]) that are indicative of an immune disease.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Croonenberghs | first1 = J. | last2 = Wauters | first2 = A. | last3 = Devreese | first3 = K. | last4 = Verkerk | first4 = R. | last5 = Scharpe | first5 = S. | last6 = Bosmans | first6 = E. | last7 = Egyed | first7 = B. | last8 = Deboutte | first8 = D. | last9 = Maes | first9 = M. | title = Increased serum albumin, γ globulin, immunoglobulin IgG, and IgG2 and IgG4 in autism | doi = 10.1017/S0033291702006037 | journal = Psychological Medicine | volume = 32 | issue = 8 | year = 2002 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Gupta | first1 = S. | last2 = Aggarwal | first2 = S. | last3 = Rashanravan | first3 = B. | last4 = Lee | first4 = T. | title = Th1- and Th2-like cytokines in CD4+ and CD8+ T cells in autism | doi = 10.1016/S0165-5728(98)00021-6 | journal = Journal of Neuroimmunology | volume = 85 | issue = 1 | pages = 106–109 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9627004| pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Ashwood | first1 = P. | last2 = Wakefield | first2 = A. J. | doi = 10.1016/j.jneuroim.2005.12.007 | title = Immune activation of peripheral blood and mucosal CD3+ lymphocyte cytokine profiles in children with autism and gastrointestinal symptoms | journal = Journal of Neuroimmunology | volume = 173 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 126–134 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16494951| pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Zimmerman | first1 = A. W. | last2 = Jyonouchi | first2 = H. | last3 = Comi | first3 = A. M. | last4 = Connors | first4 = S. L. | last5 = Milstien | first5 = S. | last6 = Varsou | first6 = A. | last7 = Heyes | first7 = M. P. | doi = 10.1016/j.pediatrneurol.2005.03.014 | title = Cerebrospinal Fluid and Serum Markers of Inflammation in Autism | journal = Pediatric Neurology | volume = 33 | issue = 3 | pages = 195–201 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16139734| pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Molloy | first1 = C. | last2 = Morrow | first2 = A. | last3 = Meinzen-Derr | first3 = J. | last4 = Schleifer | first4 = K. | last5 = Dienger | first5 = K. | last6 = Manning-Courtney | first6 = P. | last7 = Altaye | first7 = M. | last8 = Wills-Karp | first8 = M. | doi = 10.1016/j.jneuroim.2005.11.007 | title = Elevated cytokine levels in children with autism spectrum disorder | journal = Journal of Neuroimmunology | volume = 172 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 198–205 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16360218| pmc = }}</ref> One publication speculated that the lack of early childhood exposure could be a cause of autism.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Becker | first1 = K. G. | title = Autism, asthma, inflammation, and the hygiene hypothesis | doi = 10.1016/j.mehy.2007.02.019 | journal = Medical Hypotheses | volume = 69 | issue = 4 | pages = 731–740 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17412520| pmc =2048743 }}</ref>
The risk of chronic inflammatory diseases also depends on factors such as diet, pollution, physical activity, obesity, socio-economic factors and stress. Genetic predisposition is also a factor.<ref name= rockgaw /><ref name=filippi2008>{{cite journal |vauthors=Filippi CM, von Herrath MG | year = 2008 | title = Viral trigger for type 1 diabetes: pros and cons | journal = Diabetes | volume = 57 | issue = 11| pages = 2863–2871 | doi=10.2337/db07-1023 | pmid=18971433 | pmc=2570378}}</ref><ref name=rook2012>{{cite journal | author = Rook GA | year = 2012 | title = Hygiene hypothesis and autoimmune diseases | url = | journal = Clin Rev Allergy Immunol | volume = 42 | issue = 1| pages = 5–15 | doi=10.1007/s12016-011-8285-8| pmid = 22090147 }}</ref>
== History ==
=== Hygiene ===
Although the idea that exposure to certain infections may decrease the risk of allergy is not new, Strachan was one of the first to formally propose it, in an article published in the ''[[British Medical Journal]]'' in 1989.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.299.6710.1259 |title=Hay fever, hygiene, and household size |year=1989 |last1=Strachan |first1=D. P. |journal=BMJ |volume=299 |issue=6710 |pages=1259–60 |pmid=2513902 |pmc=1838109}}</ref> This article proposed to explain the observation that [[hay fever]] and [[eczema]], both allergic diseases, were less common in children from larger families, which were presumably exposed to more infectious agents through their siblings, than in children from families with only one child.
The hypothesis was extensively investigated by [[immunology|immunologists]] and [[epidemiology|epidemiologists]] and has become an important theoretical framework for the study of chronic inflammatory disorders. It explains the increase in allergic diseases that has been seen since industrialization and the higher incidence of allergic diseases in more developed countries. Epidemiological studies continue to confirm the protective effect of large family size and of growing up on a farm. However, exposure to common childhood infections such as chickenpox or measles is not thought to be protective.
=== Old friends ===
The "old friends hypothesis" proposed in 2003<ref name=rook2003/> may offer a better explanation for the link between microbial exposure and inflammatory diseases.<ref name=rook2013/><ref name=rook2003/> This hypothesis argues that the vital exposures are not common childhood and other recently evolved infections, which are no older than 10,000 years, but rather microbes already present in hunter-gatherer times when the human immune system was evolving. Conventional childhood infections are mostly "[[crowd infections]]" that kill or immunise and thus cannot persist in isolated hunter-gatherer groups. Crowd infections started to appear after the [[neolithic agriculture|neolithic agricultural]] revolution, when human populations increased in size and proximity. The microbes that co-evolved with mammalian immune systems are much more ancient. According to this hypothesis, humans became so dependent on them that their immune systems can neither develop nor function properly without them.
Rook proposed that these microbes most likely include:
* Ambient species that exist in the same environments as humans * Species that inhabit human skin, gut and respiratory tract, and that of the animals we live with * Organisms such as [[virus]]es and [[helminth]]s (worms) that establish chronic infections or carrier states that humans can tolerate and so could co-evolve a specific immunoregulatory relationship with the immune system.
The modified hypothesis later expanded to include exposure to [[symbiotic]] bacteria and parasites.<ref name=grammatikos2008>{{cite journal | author = Grammatikos Alexandros P | year = 2008 | title = The genetic and environmental basis of atopic diseases | url = | journal = Annals of Medicine | volume = 40 | issue = 7| pages = 482–95 | doi = 10.1080/07853890802082096 | pmid = 18608118 }}</ref>
"Evolution turns the inevitable into a necessity." This means that the majority of mammalian evolution took place in mud and rotting vegetation and more than 90 percent of human evolution took place in isolated hunter-gatherer communities and farming communities. Therefore, the human immune systems have evolved to anticipate certain types of microbial input, making the inevitable exposure into a necessity. The organisms that are implicated in the hygiene hypothesis are not proven to cause the disease prevalence, however there are sufficient data on lactobacilli, saprophytic environment mycobacteria, and helminths and their association. These bacteria and parasites have commonly been found in vegetation, mud, and water throughout evolution.<ref name=rook2013/><ref name=rook2003/>
Multiple possible mechanisms have been proposed for how the 'Old Friends' microorganisms prevent autoimmune diseases and asthma. They include: # Reciprocal inhibition between immune responses directed against distinct antigens of the Old Friends microbes which elicit stronger immune responses than the weaker autoantigens and allergens of autoimmune disease and allergy respectively. # Competition for cytokines, MHC receptors and growth factors needed by the immune system to mount an immune response. # Immunoregulatory interactions with host TLRs.<ref name=Okada2010/>
=== Microbial diversity ===
The "microbial diversity" hypothesis, proposed by Paolo Matricardi<ref name=matricardi2010>{{cite journal | author = Matricardi PM | year = 2010 | title = 99th Dahlem conference on infection, inflammation and chronic inflammatory disorders: controversial aspects of the 'hygiene hypothesis' | url = | journal = Clin Exp Immunol | volume = 160 | issue = 1| pages = 98–105 | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2249.2010.04130.x| pmid = 20415858 | pmc = 2841842 }}</ref> and developed by von Hertzen,<ref name=vonhertzen2011>{{cite journal |vauthors=von Hertzen L, Hanski I, Haahtela T | year = 2011 | title = Natural immunity. Biodiversity loss and inflammatory diseases are two global megatrends that might be related | doi = 10.1038/embor.2011.195 | journal = EMBO Rep | volume = 12 | issue = 11| pages = 1089–1093 | pmc = 3207110 }}</ref> holds that diversity and turnover of bacterial species in the [[gut mucosa]] and other sites is a key factor for priming and regulating the immune system, rather than stable colonization with a particular species. It is not clear whether diversity per se, or that a diverse population will include certain organisms without which the immune system fails to develop. Rook likened the embryonic immune system to a computer that contains programmes but little data. During gestation and infancy exposure to diverse organisms builds a "database" that allows the immune system to identify and respond to harmful agents and normalize once the danger is eliminated.
For allergic disease, the most important times for exposure are: early in development; later during pregnancy; and the first few days or months of infancy. Exposure needs to be maintained over a significant period. This fits with evidence that delivery by [[Caesarean section]] may be associated with increased allergies, whilst breastfeeding can be protective.<ref name=stanwellsmith /> The extent to which exposures need to be maintained after infancy and whether these conditions could be managed by on-going exposure is as yet unknown.
== Evolution of the adaptive immune system ==
Humans and the microbes they harbor have co-evolved for thousands of centuries; however, it is thought that the human species has gone through numerous phases in history characterized by different pathogen exposures. For instance, in very early human societies, small interaction between its members has given particular selection to a relatively limited group of pathogens that had high transmission rates. When societies became larger, the introduction of agriculture some 10,000 years ago made the spreading of new pathogens more likely, and thus exposures to pathogens that favored high population densities to thrive. Furthermore, pastoralism has made zoonotic pathogen transmissions even more favorable. It is considered that the human immune system is likely subjected to a selective pressure from pathogens that are responsible for down regulating certain alleles and therefore phenotypes in humans, the thalassemia genes that are shaped by the ''Plasmodium'' species expressing the selection pressure being a model for this theory.
Recent comparative genomic studies have shown that immune response genes (protein coding and non-coding regulatory genes) have less evolutionary constraint, and are rather more frequently targeted by positive selection from pathogens that coevolve with the human subject. Of all the various types of pathogens known to cause disease in humans, helminths warrant special attention, because of their ability to modify the prevalence or severity of certain immune-related responses in human and mouse models. In fact recent research has shown that parasitic worms have served as a stronger selective pressure on select human genes encoding interleukins and interleukin receptors when compared to viral and bacterial pathogens. Helminths are thought to have been as old as the [[adaptive immune system]], suggesting that they may have co-evolved, also implying that our immune system has been strongly focused on fighting off helminthic infections, insofar as to potentially interact with them early in infancy. The host-pathogen interaction is a very important relationship that serves to shape the immune system development early on in life.<ref>Sironi, Manuela, and Mario Clerici. "The Hygiene Hypothesis: An Evolutionary Perspective." Microbes and Infection: 421-27</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Wolfe N.D. |author2=Dunavan C.P. |author3=Diamond J. | year = 2007 | title = Origins of major human infectious diseases | url = | journal = Nature | volume = 447 | issue = 7142| pages = 279–283 | doi=10.1038/nature05775|bibcode=2007Natur.447..279W}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Kosiol C. |author2=Vinar T. |author3=Hubisz M.J. |author4=Bustamante C.D. |author5=Nielsen R. |author6=Siepel A. | year = 2008 | title = Patterns of positive selection in six mammalian genomes | journal = PLoS Genet | volume = 4 | issue = 8| page = e1000144 | doi=10.1371/journal.pgen.1000144 | pmid=18670650 | pmc=2483296}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Fumagalli M. |author2=Pozzoli U. |author3=Cagliani R. |author4=Comi G.P. |author5=Riva S. |author6=Clerici M. |author7=Bresolin N. |author8=Sironi M. | year = 2009 | title = Parasites represent a major selective force for interleukin genes and shape the genetic predisposition to autoimmune conditions | url = | journal = J. Exp. Med. | volume = 206| issue = 6| page = 206 | doi=10.1084/jem.20082779}}</ref>
== Biological basis ==
Allergic conditions are caused by inappropriate immunological responses to harmless [[antigens]] driven by a [[t helper cell|T<sub>H</sub>2]]-mediated immune response, T<sub>H</sub>2 cells produce [[interleukin 4]], [[interleukin 5]], [[interleukin 6]], [[interleukin 13]] and predominantly [[immunoglobulin E]].<ref name=Okada2010/> Many [[bacteria]] and [[virus]]es elicit a [[t helper cell|T<sub>H</sub>1]]-mediated immune response, which down-regulates T<sub>H</sub>2 responses. T<sub>H</sub>1 immune responses are characterized by the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as [[interleukin 2]], [[IFNγ]], and [[TNFα]]. Factors that favor a predominantly T<sub>H</sub>1 phenotype include: older siblings, large family size, early day care attendance, infection (TB, measles, or hepatitis), rural living, or contact with animals. A T<sub>H</sub>2-dominated phenotype is associated with high antibiotic use, western lifestyle, urban environment, diet, and sensitivity to dust mites and cockroaches. T<sub>H</sub>1 and T<sub>H</sub>2 responses are reciprocally inhibitory, so when one is active, the other is suppressed.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Kramer| year = 2013 | title = Maintaining Health by Balancing Microbial Exposure and Prevention of Infection: the Hygiene Hypothesis versus the Hypothesis of Early Immune Challenge | url = | journal = Journal of Hospital Infection | volume = 83 | issue = | page = 51 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> <ref>Lee et. al. "Inflammatory Bowel Disease." 2014. Evolution, Medicine, and Public Health. P.95.</ref> <ref>{{cite journal | author = Weinberg | year = 2000 | title = Urbanization and Childhood Asthma: An African Perspective | url = | journal = Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology | volume = 105 | issue = 2| pages = 224–231 | doi=10.1016/s0091-6749(00)90069-1}}</ref>
The mechanism of action of the hygiene hypothesis was insufficient stimulation of the T<sub>H</sub>1 arm, stimulating the cell defence of the immune system and leading to an overactive mother T<sub>H</sub>2 arm, stimulating the antibody-mediated immunity of the immune systems, which in turn led to allergic disease.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0167-5699(00)01582-6 |title=Do common childhood infections 'teach' the immune system not to be allergic? |year=2000 |last1=Folkerts |first1=Gert |last2=Walzl |first2=Gerhard |last3=Openshaw |first3=Peter J.M. |journal=Immunology Today |volume=21 |issue=3 |pages=118–20 |pmid=10777250}}</ref>
{{citation style|date=April 2015}} This explanation however, cannot explain the rise in incidence (similar to the rise of allergic diseases) of several T<sub>H</sub>1-mediated [[autoimmunity|autoimmune diseases]], including [[inflammatory bowel disease]], [[multiple sclerosis]] and [[Diabetes mellitus type 1|type I diabetes]]. [Figure 1Bach] However, the North South Gradient seen in the prevalence of multiple sclerosis has been found to be inversely related to the global distribution of parasitic infection.[Figure 2Bach] Additionally, research has shown that MS patients infected with parasites displayed T<sub>H</sub>2 type immune responses as opposed to the proinflammatory T<sub>H</sub>1 immune phenotype seen in non-infected multiple sclerosis patients.[Fleming] Parasite infection has also been shown to improve inflammatory bowel disease and may act in a similar fashion as it does in multiple sclerosis.[Lee]
An alternative explanation is that the developing immune system must receive stimuli (from infectious agents, symbiotic bacteria, or parasites) to adequately develop [[regulatory T cell]]s. Without that stimuli it becomes more susceptible to autoimmune diseases and allergic diseases, because of insufficiently repressed T<sub>H</sub>1 and T<sub>H</sub>2 responses, respectively.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.iac.2005.03.005 |title=The Hygiene Hypothesis Revisited |year=2005 |last1=Bufford |first1=Jeremy D. |last2=Gern |first2=James E. |journal=Immunology and Allergy Clinics of North America |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=247–62, v–vi |pmid=15878454 }}</ref> For example, all chronic inflammatory disorders show evidence of failed immunoregulation.<ref name=rockgaw>{{cite journal | author = Rook GAW | date = Apr 2010 | title = 99th Dahlem conference on infection, inflammation and chronic inflammatory disorders: darwinian medicine and the 'hygiene' or 'old friends' hypothesis | url = | journal = Clin Exp Immunol | volume = 160 | issue = 1| pages = 70–9 | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2249.2010.04133.x| pmid = 20415854 | pmc = 2841838 }}</ref> Secondly, helminths, non-pathogenic ambient pseudocommensal bacteria or certain gut [[commensal]]s and [[probiotics]], drive immunoregulation. They block or treat models of all chronic inflammatory conditions.<ref name= round2011>{{cite journal |vauthors=Round JL, Lee SM, Li J, Tran G, Jabri B, Chatila TA, Mazmanian SK | date = May 2011 | title = The Toll-like receptor 2 pathway establishes colonization by a commensal of the human microbiota | url = | journal = Science | volume = 332 | issue = 6032| pages = 974–7 | doi=10.1126/science.1206095| pmid = 21512004 | pmc = 3164325 | bibcode = 2011Sci...332..974R}}</ref><ref name=osada2010>{{cite journal |vauthors=Osada Y, Kanazawa T | year = 2010 | title = Parasitic helminths: new weapons against immunological disorders | url = | journal = J Biomed Biotechnol | volume = 2010 | issue = | pages = 743–58 }}</ref> Thirdly, some such organisms (or molecules that they secrete), specifically expand populations of regulatory T cells (Treg),<ref name= round2011 /><ref name=grainger2010>{{cite journal |vauthors=Grainger JR, Smith KA, Hewitson JP, McSorley HJ, Harcus Y, Filbey KJ, Finney CA, Greenwood EJ, Knox DP, Wilson MS, Belkaid Y, Rudensky AY, Maizels RM | year = 2010 | title = Helminth secretions induce de novo T cell Foxp3 expression and regulatory function through the TGF-beta pathway | url = | journal = J Exp Med | volume = 207 | issue = 11| pages = 2331–41 | doi=10.1084/jem.20101074| pmid = 20876311 | pmc = 2964568 }}</ref> or cause [[dendritic cells]] to switch to regulatory forms that preferentially drive immunoregulation.<ref name=smits2005>{{cite journal |vauthors=Smits HH, Engering A, van der Kleij D, de Jong EC, Schipper K, van Capel TM, Zaat BA, Yazdanbakhsh M, Wierenga EA, van Kooyk Y, Kapsenberg ML | date = Jun 2005 | title = Selective probiotic bacteria induce IL-10-producing regulatory T cells in vitro by modulating dendritic cell function through dendritic cell-specific intercellular adhesion molecule 3-grabbing nonintegrin | url = | journal = J Allergy Clin Immunol | volume = 115 | issue = 6| pages = 1260–7 | doi=10.1016/j.jaci.2005.03.036| pmid = 15940144 }}</ref> Finally, when multiple sclerosis patients become infected with helminths, the disease stops progressing and circulating myelin-recognising regulatory T cells appear in the [[peripheral blood]].<ref name=correale2007>{{cite journal |vauthors=Correale J, Farez M | date = Feb 2007 | title = Association between parasite infection and immune responses in multiple sclerosis | url = | journal = Ann Neurol | volume = 61 | issue = 2| pages = 97–108 | doi=10.1002/ana.21067 | pmid=17230481}}</ref> This indicates that helminths act as [[adjuvant]]s for [[regulatory T cell]]s. This observation led to [[clinical trial]]s.<ref name=fleming2011>{{cite journal |vauthors=Fleming J, Isaak A, Lee J, Luzzio C, Carrithers M, Cook T, Field A, Boland J, Fabry Z | date = Mar 2011 | title = Probiotic helminth administration in relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis: a phase 1 study | url = | journal = Mult Scler | volume = 17 | issue = 6| pages = 743–54 | doi=10.1177/1352458511398054| pmid = 21372112 | pmc = 3894910 }}</ref>
== Epidemiological evidence == {{medref|section|date=May 2016}}
The hygiene hypothesis is supported by epidemiological data. Studies have shown that various immunological and autoimmune diseases are much less common in the developing world than the industrialized world and that immigrants to the industrialized world from the developing world increasingly develop immunological disorders in relation to the length of time since arrival in the industrialized world.<ref name=Okada2010/> This is true for asthma<ref name="pmid12910582">{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/ppul.10323 |title=Migration to a western country increases asthma symptoms but not eosinophilic airway inflammation |year=2003 |last1=Gibson |first1=Peter G. |last2=Henry |first2=Richard L. |last3=Shah |first3=Smita |last4=Powell |first4=Heather |last5=Wang |first5=He |journal=Pediatric Pulmonology |volume=36 |issue=3 |pages=209–15 |pmid=12910582}}</ref> and other chronic inflammatory disorders.<ref name=rook2013 />
Recently, ''[[Opisthorchis felineus]]'' chronic helminthic infection in the endemic region of Russia was found to be associated with lower total [[serum cholesterol]] levels and a significant attenuation of [[atherosclerosis]] in humans.<ref name=magen2013>{{cite journal |author1=Magen Eli |author2=Bychkov Vitaly |author3=Ginovker Alexander |author4=Kashuba Eduard | year = 2013 | title = Chronic Opisthorchis felineus infection attenuates atherosclerosis – an autopsy study | url = | journal = International Journal for Parasitology | volume = 43 | issue = 10| pages = 819–24 | doi = 10.1016/j.ijpara.2013.04.008 | pmid = 23792298 }}</ref>
In developed countries where childhood diseases were eliminated, the asthma rate for youth is approximately 10%. In the 19th century, hay-fever, an easily recognisable allergy, was a very rare condition.<ref name=backley1873>Blackley CH (1873) Experimental Researches on the Causes and Nature of Catarrhus Aestivus (Hay-fever and Hay-asthma) (Baillière Tindall and Cox, London).</ref>
Longitudinal studies in Ghana demonstrate an increase in immunological disorders as it grew more affluent and presumably cleaner.<ref name=pmid17326711>{{cite journal |doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.0040070 |title=Exercise-Induced Bronchospasm and Atopy in Ghana: Two Surveys Ten Years Apart |year=2007 |last1=Addo-Yobo |first1=Emmanuel O. D. |last2=Woodcock |first2=Ashley |last3=Allotey |first3=Adorkor |last4=Baffoe-Bonnie |first4=Benjamin |last5=Strachan |first5=David |last6=Custovic |first6=Adnan |journal=PLoS Medicine |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=e70 |pmid=17326711 |pmc=1808098}}</ref> These results have been replicated by Weinberg et al. who amassed data from a variety of African countries comparing urban and rural environments as well as high and low socioeconomic status (SES). In all four countries urban and high SES groups had a higher prevalence of exercise induced bronchospasm.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Weinberg | year = 2000| title = Urbanization and Childhood Asthma: An African Perspective." 2000 | url = | journal = Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology | volume = 105 | issue = 2| pages = 224–231 | doi=10.1016/s0091-6749(00)90069-1}}</ref> The use of antibiotics in the first year of life has been linked to asthma and other allergic diseases.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1378/chest.129.3.610 |title=Does Antibiotic Exposure During Infancy Lead to Development of Asthma?: A Systematic Review and Metaanalysis |year=2006 |last1=Marra |first1=F. |journal=Chest |volume=129 |issue=3 |pages=610–8 |pmid=16537858 |last2=Lynd |first2=L |last3=Coombes |first3=M |last4=Richardson |first4=K |last5=Legal |first5=M |last6=Fitzgerald |first6=JM |last7=Marra |first7=CA}}</ref> The use of antibacterial cleaning products has also been associated with higher incidence of [[asthma]]. Increased asthma rates are associated with birth by [[Caesarean section]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2222.2007.02780.x |title=A meta-analysis of the association between Caesarean section and childhood asthma |year=2008 |last1=Thavagnanam |first1=S. |last2=Fleming |first2=J. |last3=Bromley |first3=A. |last4=Shields |first4=M. D. |last5=Cardwell |first5=C. R. |journal=Clinical & Experimental Allergy |volume=38 |issue=4 |pages=629–33 |pmid=18352976}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1164/rccm.200612-1793OC |title=The Use of Household Cleaning Sprays and Adult Asthma |year=2007 |last1=Zock |first1=Jan-Paul |last2=Plana |first2=Estel |last3=Jarvis |first3=Deborah |last4=Antó |first4=Josep M. |last5=Kromhout |first5=Hans |last6=Kennedy |first6=Susan M. |last7=Künzli |first7=Nino |last8=Villani |first8=Simona |last9=Olivieri |first9=Mario |last10=Torén |first10=Kjell |last11=Radon |first11=Katja |last12=Sunyer |first12=Jordi |last13=Dahlman-Hoglund |first13=Anna |last14=Norbäck |first14=Dan |last15=Kogevinas |first15=Manolis |journal=American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine |volume=176 |issue=8 |pages=735–41 |pmid=17585104 |pmc=2020829}}</ref> The data supporting links to antibiotic use and caesarean section (but not to antibacterial use) are rapidly strengthening.<ref name=magnus2011>{{cite journal |vauthors=Magnus MC, Haberg SE, Stigum H, Nafstad P, London SJ, Vangen S, Nystad W | date = Dec 2011 | title = Delivery by Cesarean section and early childhood respiratory symptoms and disorders: the Norwegian mother and child cohort study | url = | journal = Am J Epidemiol | volume = 174 | issue = 11| pages = 1275–85 | doi=10.1093/aje/kwr242| pmid = 22038100 | pmc = 3254156 }}</ref><ref name=metsala2013>{{cite journal |vauthors=Metsala J, Lundqvist A, Virta LJ, Kaila M, Gissler M, Virtanen SM | year = 2013 | title = Mother's and offspring's use of antibiotics and infant allergy to cow's milk | url = | journal = Epidemiology | volume = 24 | issue = 2| pages = 303–309 | doi=10.1097/ede.0b013e31827f520f}}</ref>
Antibiotic usage, which reduces the diversity of gut microbiota, is another cited factor. Although several studies have shown associations between antibiotic use and later development of asthma or allergy, other studies suggest that the effect is due to more frequent antibiotic use in asthmatic children. Trends in vaccine use may also be relevant, but epidemiological studies provide no consistent support for a detrimental effect of vaccination/immunization on [[atopy]] rates.<ref name=stanwellsmith /> In support of the old friends hypothesis, the intestinal microbiome was found to differ between allergic and non-allergic Estonian and Swedish children (although this finding was not replicated in a larger cohort), and the biodiversity of the intestinal flora in patients with Crohn’s disease was diminished.<ref name=Okada2010/>
In 2015, a study found that washing dishes by hand as opposed to using a dishwasher, along with eating food directly from a farm or fermented food, might lead to reduced risk of certain conditions, including asthma, eczema, and possibly hay fever, though the data found on hay fever was not regarded as [[Statistical significant|statistically significant]]. It was stated, however, that more research was needed to determine if there was an [[Correlation does not imply causation|actual causal effect]] between these practices and a reduced risk of allergies and asthma.<ref name="dishes">{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/science/sciencenow/la-sci-sn-hand-washing-allergies-20150223-story.html|title=How hand-washing dishes may prevent kids from getting allergies|first=Deborah|last=Netburn|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=February 23, 2015|accessdate=February 26, 2015}}</ref>
== Experimental evidence ==
One study showed that [[Staphylococci]] helped reduce inflammation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/8373690.stm| title=Dirt can be good for children, say scientists| publisher=BBC News| date=23 November 2009| accessdate=2012-04-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/nm.2062 |title=Commensal bacteria regulate Toll-like receptor 3–dependent inflammation after skin injury |year=2009|last1=Lai |first1=Yuping |last2=Di Nardo |first2=Anna |last3=Nakatsuji |first3=Teruaki |last4=Leichtle |first4=Anke |last5=Yang |first5=Yan |last6=Cogen |first6=AnnaL|last7=Wu|first7=ZiRong|last8=Hooper |first8=Lora V |last9=Schmidt |first9=Richard R |last10=Von Aulock |first10=Sonja |last11=Radek |first11=Katherine A |last12=Huang |first12=Chun-Ming|last13=Ryan|first13=Allen F |last14=Gallo |first14=Richard L |journal=Nature Medicine |volume=15 |issue=12 |pages=1377–82 |pmid=19966777 |pmc=2880863}}</ref> Early life exposure to specific microbe-enriched environments decreases susceptibility to diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease and asthma, whereas its absence, as in antibiotic treatment during childhood, may have the opposite effect.{{Citation needed|date=July 2015}}<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/science.1219328 |title=Microbial Exposure During Early Life Has Persistent Effects on Natural Killer T Cell Function |year=2012 |last1=Olszak |first1=T. |last2=An |first2=D. |last3=Zeissig |first3=S. |last4=Vera |first4=M. P. |last5=Richter |first5=J. |last6=Franke |first6=A. |last7=Glickman |first7=J. N. |last8=Siebert |first8=R. |last9=Baron |first9=R. M. |last10=Kasper |first10=D. L. |last11=Blumberg |first11=R. S. |journal=Science |volume=336 |issue=6080 |pages=489–93 |pmid=22442383 |pmc=3437652|bibcode = 2012Sci...336..489O }}</ref>
== Public health trends ==
Since allergies and other chronic inflammatory diseases are largely diseases of the last 100 years or so, the "hygiene" revolution of the last 200 years came under scrutiny as a possible cause. During the 1800s radical improvements to sanitation and water quality occurred in Europe and North America. The introduction of toilets and sewer systems and the cleanup of city streets, and cleaner food were part of this program. This in turn led to a rapid decline in infectious diseases, particularly during the period 1900-1950, through reduced exposure to infectious agents.<ref name=stanwellsmith /><ref name=Bloomfield />
Public health activities have also played a part in affecting diet and lifestyle, such as physical activity levels and locations.
It has been suggested that public awareness of the initial form of the "hygiene hypothesis" has led to an "increased disregard" for hygiene in the home.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0956713513003745 | doi=10.1016/j.foodcont.2013.07.026 | volume=35 | title=Hygiene in the home kitchen: Changes in behaviour and impact of key microbiological hazard control measures | journal=Food Control | pages=392–400| year=2014 | last1=Taché | first1=J. | last2=Carpentier | first2=B. }}</ref>
== Treatment ==
While no hygiene-related treatments are part of the standard of care, various approaches are under investigation. Helminth therapy is one alternative.<ref name= fleming2011/> [[Probiotic]]s (drinks or foods) have never been shown to reintroduce microbes to the gut. As yet, therapeutically relevant microbes have not been specifically identified.<ref name=sanders2013>{{cite journal | author = Sanders ME, Guarner F, Guerrant R, Holt PR, Quigley EM, Sartor RB, Sherman PM, Mayer EA | date = May 2013 | title = An update on the use and investigation of probiotics in health and disease | url = | journal = Gut | volume = 62 | issue = 5| pages = 787–96 | doi=10.1136/gutjnl-2012-302504| pmid = 23474420 | pmc = 4351195 }}</ref>
Lifestyle changes could increase microbial exposure, but whether this on balance improves the balance of risks remains the subject of research. Proposals include natural childbirth, sustained breast feeding and physical interaction between siblings, and encouraging children to spend more time in "uncleaned" outdoor environments.
Should these therapies become accepted, public policy implications include providing green spaces in urban areas or even providing access to agricultural environments for children.<ref name="gaw in press">{{cite journal | author = Rook GA | date = Oct 2013 | title = Regulation of the immune system by biodiversity from the natural environment: an ecosystem service essential to health | url = | journal = PNAS | volume = 110| issue = 46| pages = 18360–18367| doi = 10.1073/pnas.1313731110 | bibcode = 2013PNAS..11018360R| pmc = 3831972}}</ref>
=== Helminthic therapy === {{Main article|Helminthic therapy}} {{See also|Effects of parasitic worms on the immune system}}
Helminthic therapy is the treatment of [[autoimmune disease]]s and [[immune disorder]]s by means of deliberate infestation with a [[helminth]] [[larva]] or [[Ovum|ova]]. Helminthic therapy is currently being studied as a promising treatment for several (non-viral) [[autoimmune disease]]s including [[Crohn's disease]],<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.0269-2813.2004.01803.x |title=Helminths as therapeutic agents for inflammatory bowel disease |year=2004 |last1=Hunter |first1=M. M. |last2=McKay |first2=D. M. |journal=Alimentary Pharmacology and Therapeutics |volume=19 |issue=2 |pages=167–77 |pmid=14723608}}</ref><ref name="pmid16344586">{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/gut.2005.079129 |title=A proof of concept study establishing Necator americanus in Crohn's patients and reservoir donors |year=2006 |last1=Croese |first1=J |journal=Gut |volume=55 |pages=136–7 |pmid=16344586 |last2=O'Neil |first2=J |last3=Masson |first3=J |last4=Cooke |first4=S |last5=Melrose |first5=W |last6=Pritchard |first6=D |last7=Speare |first7=R |issue=1 |pmc=1856386}}</ref><ref name="pmid15591509">{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/gut.2004.041749 |title=Trichuris suis therapy in Crohn's disease |year=2005 |last1=Summers |first1=R W |journal=Gut |volume=54 |pages=87–90 |pmid=15591509 |last2=Elliott |first2=DE |last3=Urban Jr |first3=JF |last4=Thompson |first4=R |last5=Weinstock |first5=JV |issue=1 |pmc=1774382}}</ref><ref name="pmid14499784">{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1572-0241.2003.07660.x |title=Trichuris suis seems to be safe and possibly effective in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease |year=2003 |last1=Summers |first1=Robert W. |last2=Elliott |first2=David E. |last3=Qadir |first3=Khurram |last4=Urban Jr |first4=Joseph F. |last5=Thompson |first5=Robin |last6=Weinstock |first6=Joel V. |journal=The American Journal of Gastroenterology |volume=98 |issue=9 |pages=2034–41 |pmid=14499784}}</ref> multiple sclerosis,<ref name="pmid17230481">{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/ana.21067 |title=Association between parasite infection and immune responses in multiple sclerosis |year=2007 |last1=Correale |first1=Jorge |last2=Farez |first2=Mauricio |journal=Annals of Neurology |volume=61 |issue=2 |pages=97–108 |pmid=17230481}}</ref> asthma,<ref name="pmid15780835">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.pt.2005.02.002 |title=Parasite role reversal: Worms on trial |year=2005 |last1=Falcone |first1=Franco H. |last2=Pritchard |first2=David I. |journal=Trends in Parasitology |volume=21 |issue=4 |pages=157–60 |pmid=15780835}}</ref><ref name=pmid16778161>{{cite journal |doi=10.1164/rccm.200603-331OC |title=Asthma and Current Intestinal Parasite Infection |year=2006 |last1=Leonardi-Bee |first1=Jo |last2=Pritchard |first2=David |last3=Britton |first3=John |journal=American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine |volume=174 |issue=5 |pages=514–23 |pmid=16778161}}</ref> and [[ulcerative colitis]].<ref name="pmid15825065">{{cite journal |doi=10.1053/j.gastro.2005.01.005 |title=Trichuris suis therapy for active ulcerative colitis: A randomized controlled trial |year=2005 |last1=Summers |first1=Robert W. |last2=Elliott |first2=David E. |last3=Urban Jr |first3=Joseph F. |last4=Thompson |first4=Robin A. |last5=Weinstock |first5=Joel V. |journal=Gastroenterology |volume=128 |issue=4 |pages=825–32 |pmid=15825065}}</ref> Autoimmune liver disease can be modulated by active helminth infections.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=17488925 |year=2007 |last1=Aoyama |first1=H |last2=Hirata |first2=T |last3=Sakugawa |first3=H |last4=Watanabe |first4=T |last5=Miyagi |first5=S |last6=Maeshiro |first6=T |last7=Chinen |first7=T |last8=Kawane |first8=M |last9=Zaha |first9=O |last10=Nakayoshi |first10=T |last11=Kinjo |first11=F |last12=Fujita |first12=J |title=An inverse relationship between autoimmune liver diseases and Strongyloides stercoralis infection |volume=76 |issue=5 |pages=972–6 |journal=The American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene}}</ref>
The anti-inflammatory effects of helminth infection are prompting interest and research into diseases that involve inflammation but that are not currently considered to include autoimmunity or immune dysregulation as a causative factor. Heart disease and arteriosclerosis both have similar epidemiological profiles as autoimmune diseases and both involve inflammation. Their increased incidence cannot be solely attributed to environmental factors. Recent research explored the eradication of helminths as contributing to this discrepancy.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.mehy.2004.09.028 |title=Can worms defend our hearts? Chronic helminthic infections may attenuate the development of cardiovascular diseases |year=2005 |last1=Magen |first1=Eli |last2=Borkow |first2=Gadi |last3=Bentwich |first3=Zvi |last4=Mishal |first4=Joseph |last5=Scharf |first5=Shimon |journal=Medical Hypotheses |volume=64 |issue=5 |pages=904–9 |pmid=15780483}}</ref>
Helminthic therapy emerged from the search for reasons why the incidence of immunological disorders and autoimmune diseases correlates with the level of industrial development.<ref name=pmid16778161/><ref name="pmid 12127652">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0303-8467(02)00036-7 |title=The worldwide prevalence of multiple sclerosis |year=2002 |last1=Pugliatti |first1=Maura |last2=Sotgiu |first2=Stefano |last3=Rosati |first3=Giulio |journal=Clinical Neurology and Neurosurgery |volume=104 |issue=3 |pages=182–91 |pmid=12127652}}</ref><ref name="pmid 12127652" /><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1365-3024.2006.00879.x |title=Parasitic worms and inflammatory diseases |year=2006 |last1=Zaccone |first1=P. |last2=Fehervari |first2=Z. |last3=Phillips |first3=J. M. |last4=Dunne |first4=D. W. |last5=Cooke |first5=A. |journal=Parasite Immunology |volume=28 |issue=10 |pages=515–23 |pmid=16965287 |pmc=1618732}}</ref><ref name="pmid 14684567">{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/gut.53.1.7 |title=Helminths and harmony |year=2004 |last1=Weinstock |first1=J V |journal=Gut |volume=53 |pages=7–9 |pmid=14684567 |last2=Summers |first2=R |last3=Elliott |first3=DE |issue=1 |pmc=1773927}}</ref>
Related therapies include use other types of infectious organisms, such as protozoa.<ref name="pmid18343044">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.mehy.2008.01.024 |title=Intestinal protozoa are hypothesized to stimulate immunosurveillance against colon cancer |year=2008 |last1=Juckett |first1=David A. |last2=Aylsworth |first2=Charles F. |last3=Quensen |first3=Janet Murphy |journal=Medical Hypotheses |volume=71 |pages=104–10 |pmid=18343044 |issue=1}}</ref>
== Cleanliness == No evidence supports the idea that reducing modern practices of cleanliness and hygiene would have any impact on rates of chronic inflammatory and allergic disorders, but a significant amount of evidence that it would increase the risks of infectious diseases.<ref name=stanwellsmith/>
If home and personal cleanliness contributes to reduced exposure to vital microbes, its role is likely to be small. The idea that homes can be made “sterile” through excessive cleanliness is implausible. The evidence shows that, as fast as they are removed by cleaning, microbes are replaced, via dust and air from outdoors, by shedding from the body and other living things as well as from food.<ref name=stanwellsmith/><ref name= Bloomfield /><ref name=bloomfield2012>Bloomfield SF. Exner M, Signorelli C, Nath KJ, Scott EA. 2012. The chain of infection transmission in the home and everyday life settings, and the role of hygiene in reducing the risk of infection.http://www.ifh-homehygiene.org/best-practice-review/chain-infection-transmission-home-and-everyday-life-settings-and-role-hygiene</ref><ref name=isf>Hygiene procedures in the home and their effectiveness: a review of the scientific evidence base (2008). International Scientific Forum on Home Hygiene. http://www.ifh-homehygiene.org/best-practice-review/hygiene-procedures-home-and-their-effectiveness-review-scientific-evidence-base</ref> The key point may be that the microbial content of urban housing has altered, not because of home and personal hygiene habits, but because they are part of urban environments. Diet and lifestyle changes also affects the gut, skin and respiratory microbiota.
At the same time that concerns about allergies and other chronic inflammatory diseases have been increasing, so also have concerns about infectious disease.<ref name=stanwellsmith /><ref name= Bloomfield /><ref name=bloomfield2009>Bloomfield SF, Exner M, Fara GM, Nath KJ, Scott, EA; Van der Voorden C. The global burden of hygiene-related diseases in relation to the home and community. (2009) International Scientific Forum on Home Hygiene. http://www.ifh-homehygiene.org/review/global-burden-hygiene-related-diseases-relation-home-and-community</ref><ref name=Bloomfield2013>Bloomfield SF, Scott EA A risk assessment approach to use of antimicrobials in the home to prevent spread of infection American Journal of Infection Control 2013; 41: (5, Suppl) A1-A10, In Disinfection, Sterilization and Antisepsis: Current Issues, New Research and New Technologies. Edited by William A. Rutala and David J. Weber</ref> Infectious diseases continue to exert a heavy health toll. Preventing [[pandemics]] and reducing [[antibiotic resistance]] are global priorities. Hygiene is a cornerstone of containing these threats.
=== Infection risk management ===
The International Scientific Forum on Home Hygiene has developed a risk management approach to reducing home infection risks. This approach uses microbiological and epidemiological evidence to identify the key routes of infection transmission in the home. These data indicate that the critical routes involve the hands, hand and food contact surfaces and cleaning utensils. Clothing and household linens involve somewhat lower risks. Surfaces that contact the body, such as baths and hand basins, can act as infection vehicles, as can surfaces associated with toilets. Airborne transmission can be important for some pathogens. A key aspect of this approach is that it maximises protection against pathogens and infection, but is more relaxed about visible cleanliness in order to sustain normal exposure to other human, animal and environmental microbes.<ref name= bloomfield2012/>
== Alternative hypotheses == {{refimprove section|date=June 2016}}
There are other hypotheses that try to explain the increase in [[Allergy|allergies]] in developed nations. Major areas of focus include infant feeding, over-exposure and exposure to certain pollutants.
Infant feeding topics includes breastfeeding, when babies begin to eat solid foods and the type of these foods, cow's milk vs other milks and variations in milk processing.
Over-exposure to allergens in occupational situations can cause allergic responses, such as [[Laboratory animal allergy]], [[Bird fancier's lung|bird lung]], [[farmer's lung]] and bakers lung (See [[Wheat allergy]]).
The [[pool chlorine hypothesis]] was proposed by Albert Bernard and his colleagues as an alternative hypothesis based on [[epidemiology|epidemiological]] evidence in 2003.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/oem.60.6.385 |title=Lung hyperpermeability and asthma prevalence in schoolchildren: Unexpected associations with the attendance at indoor chlorinated swimming pools |year=2003 |last1=Bernard |first1=A |journal=Occupational and Environmental Medicine |volume=60 |issue=6 |pages=385–94 |pmid=12771389 |last2=Carbonnelle |first2=S |last3=Michel |first3=O |last4=Higuet |first4=S |last5=De Burbure |first5=C |last6=Buchet |first6=JP |last7=Hermans |first7=C |last8=Dumont |first8=X |last9=Doyle |first9=I |displayauthors=3|pmc=1740550}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Antibacterial soap]] * [[Diseases of affluence]] * [[Hookworm#Hookworm in therapy|Hookworm in therapy]] * [[Helminthic therapy]] (includes more discussion of hygiene hypothesis) * [[Vaginal seeding]] * [[Microbiomes of the built environment]]

R. | title = Microbes, immunoregulation, and the gut | doi = 10.1136/gut.2004.053785 | journal = Gut | volume = 54 | issue = 3 | pages = 317–320 | year = 2005 | pmid = 15710972| pmc =1774411 }} * {{Cite journal | last1 = Rook | first1 = G. A. W. | last2 = Adams | first2 = V. | last3 = Hunt | first3 = R. | last4 = Palmer | first4 = L. R. | last5 = Martinelli | first5 = J. | last6 = Brunet | first6 = R. | doi = 10.1007/s00281-003-0148-9 | title = Mycobacteria and other environmental organisms as immunomodulators for immunoregulatory disorders | journal = Springer Seminars in Immunopathology | volume = 25 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 237–255 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15007629| pmc = }}
